channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Deadly Blast Hits Hezbollah Neighborhood in Beirut
item.description: The explosion appeared to be the latest in a string of bombings and reprisal bombings over Hezbollah’s support for the government in neighboring Syria.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Complex Effort for Antarctic Rescue
item.description: Video and images shared on social media show the long-awaited rescue of the 52 passengers of a Russian ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, which has been trapped in ice off the coast of Antarctica since Dec. 24.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 2
item.description: Members of Indian Army band rehearsing for the Republic Day parade in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Members of Indian Army band rehearsing for the Republic Day parade on a cold winter morning in New Delhi. India will celebrate its annual Republic Day on Jan. 26.

item.title: Chinese Helicopter Rescues 52 From Ship Trapped in Antarctic Ice
item.description: The evacuation of the 52 passengers began after more than a week of attempts to approach the stranded research vessel, the Akademik Shokalskiy.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A helicopter from the nearby Chinese icebreaker Xue Long arrived to pick up the first batch of passengers from the stranded Russian ship Akademik Shokalskiy.

item.title: Body of Former Rwandan Spymaster Is Found in Johannesburg Hotel
item.description: The former military intelligence chief, Patrick Karegeya, showed signs of possible strangulation, and his supporters blamed the Rwandan government.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Letter From Europe: For Britain, Big Decisions on Identity
item.description: Britain faces many challenges this year to its national identity. Will it emerge reinvigorated in a broadening Europe, or as a footnote to its onetime global reach?
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Delhi Grocers Recall 50 Years of Changing Indian Tastes
item.description: The Steakhouse was one of the first stores that catered to a growing and aspiring middle class that sought the opportunity to partake in a slice of Western culture.
item.dc:creator: By AAYUSH SONI
item.media:description: K.D. Singh, left, and Kuldeep Shankar, right, owners of "The Steakhouse," with their mutual friend Anil Arora at the store in New Delhi in the 1960s.

item.title: Musharraf Is Taken From Court to Pakistani Military Hospital
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler, was abruptly hospitalized while on his way to a hearing on treason accusations.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Letter From India: Delhi’s New Chief Minister Strikes a Chord With the People
item.description: Arvind Kejriwal and his political party represent an evolution of both elite and mass protests in India.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal addressed the media on Saturday after taking charge as the Chief Minister in New Delhi.

item.title: Lens Blog: Photographing Hiroshima, Fukushima and Everything in Between
item.description: The career of Kikujiro Fukushima, who is still an active photojournalist at 92, spans from the aftermath of the dropping of the atomic bomb in 1945 to the Fukushima disaster of 2011.
item.dc:creator: By HIROYUKI ITO
item.media:description: Kikujiro Fukushima, the 20-year-old imperialist. He said that when he was young, he and his classmates were led to believe that killing as many enemies and dying for the emperor was the highest honor.

item.title: Attacker Sets Fire at Chinese Consulate in San Francisco
item.description: The consulate said an attacker poured two buckets of gasoline onto the front door and set it on fire, causing severe damage. No one was injured in the attack.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Downed Balloon, China and Japan Cooperate
item.description: A Chinese balloonist who attempted to land on a disputed islet in the East China Sea was rescued by the Japanese Coast Guard, a rare peaceful resolution in fiercely contested waters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Japan Coast Guard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The hot-air balloon was spotted in the East China Sea, near islands disputed by China and Japan.

item.title: India Ink: Private Schools for Poor Pressured by Right to Education Act
item.description: Schools that cannot meet the 2009 law’s infrastructure requirements, even if they cannot afford the necessary repairs, are at risk of closure.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: The Bombay South Indian Adi-Dravida Sangh School in Dharavi in Mumbai, Maharashtra. The second story of the school is presently under construction.

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Sticking Point in Peace Talks: Recognition of a Jewish State
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu argues that Palestinian recognition of Israel as a Jewish state underpins all other issues in peace negotiations, and this focus is exactly what makes it unacceptable to Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: For Prostitutes Jailed in China, Forced Labor With No Recourse
item.description: China’s murky penal system for prostitutes is similar to re-education through labor, with women being held in centers for up to two years and often required to work seven days a week for no pay.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A prostitute in Beijing known as Li Zhengguo said she would kill herself if arrested again. She is 39 and a single mother of two.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Police Stations in Anbar Attacked
item.description: Islamist militants stormed police stations in several cities of Iraq’s restive western province of Anbar on Wednesday, seizing weapon caches and freeing prisoners after security forces dismantled a Sunni protest camp on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Artifacts Taken From Museum
item.description: Nearly a hundred small artifacts, some dating back to the time of the pharaohs, are missing from a museum in southern Egypt, officials said Wednesday
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Fatal Attacks Strike a Hotel in Somalia
item.description: No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, despite threatening messages from the Islamist militant group Shabab broadcast on local radio stations in the previous 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Hawaii Tourists Revel in Sun, Surf and Semiautomatics
item.description: Many visitors from countries like Japan, where gun laws are restrictive, add shooting ranges to their must-do lists.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER
item.media:credit: Cory Lum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asami Sato, who took instruction from George White at the Royal Hawaiian Shooting Club in Honolulu, was visiting from Japan, where gun laws are strict.

item.title: Rebels Seize Portions of Strategic City in South Sudan
item.description: On the eve of negotiations to end the conflict in the country, rebel forces took major sections of Bor, giving them a foothold for a possible march toward the capital.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: As Latvia Adopts Euro, Future Growth Is Slowing
item.description: Though the process of euro enlargement has not ended, is it set to slow after Lithuania next adopts the currency in 2015.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A shopper counts her change at a supermarket in Latvia on Wednesday. Latvia is the 18th country to join the euro.

item.title: Lebanon Arrests Leader of Qaeda-Linked Group, Reports Say
item.description: The group, the Abdullah Azzam Brigades, claimed responsibility for a suicide attack on the Iranian Embassy in Beirut in November.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Ariel Sharon, Former Prime Minister of Israel, Is Said to Be Near Death
item.description: The condition of Mr. Sharon, who has been comatose for nearly eight years, has deteriorated recently, the hospital treating him said.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The medical condition of Ariel Sharon, 85, has deteriorated, a hospital spokesman said.

item.title: 2 Conservatives Join Iran Nuclear Panel
item.description: The additions to a supervisory council responsible for monitoring the country’s nuclear negotiating team appeared to strengthen the influence of critics of the talks between Iran and world powers.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Settlement News to Wait Until Kerry Leaves Israel
item.description: An Israeli official said the delay was intended to avoid a high-profile clash over new settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A released Palestinian prisoner on Tuesday. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has tied the settlement announcements to the release of Palestinian prisoners in an effort to appease his right-wing coalition members.
